questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
The figure below is a pedigree that shows the inheritance of a trait, Trait G, in a family. The presence of Trait G in an individual is determined entirely by Gene G. Gene G has 2 alleles: G, which is dominant, and g, which is recessive.

Each individual represented in the pedigree was assigned a number (shown below the symbol for the individual) for reference. Scientists determined that the Gene G genotype of Individual 20 is gg and that the Gene G genotype of Individual 21 is Gg. Based on this information, the scientists concluded that Trait G is a recessive trait.
questions.question: 1.  How many generations are shown in the figure?

questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:

questions.question: 2. Based on the figure, the 2 individuals in which of the following pairs most likely have the greatest genetic similarity across their genomes?

choices.D: Individual 18 and Individual 21

questions.question: 3. Suppose that Individual 23 and Individual 24 have 4 biological children. Based on the figure, how many of the children, if any, have Trait G ?

questions.question: 4. According to the figure, how many of the grandchildren of Individual 1 and Individual 2, if any, have Trait G ?

questions.question: 5.  Based on the figure, is it likely that Trait G is a sex-linked trait?

choices.A: Yes, because mothers with Trait G always passed Trait G to their sons.
choices.B: Yes, because mothers with Trait G did not always pass Trait G to their sons.
choices.C: No, because mothers with Trait G always passed Trait G to their sons.
choices.D: No, because mothers with Trait G did not always pass Trait G to their sons.

questions.question: 6. Based on the information provided, will an individual with the Gene G genotype  Gg have Trait G ?

choices.A: Yes, because Trait G is a dominant trait.
choices.B: Yes, because Trait G is a recessive trait.
choices.C: No, because Trait G is a dominant trait.
choices.D: No, because Trait G is a recessive trait.

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:
Heliconia metallica is a plant found in the understory of tropical rain forests. (The understory is the area below the forest canopy.) H. metallica flowers are normally pollinated by hummingbirds. The flowers can be self-pollinated (egg and pollen are from the same H. metallica plant) or cross-pollinated (egg and pollen are from different H. metallica plants). The following study was conducted to investigate the effects of different pollination treatments on fruit production and seed mass in a population of H. metallica.

Study

Before pollination could occur, the anthers (pollen-producing structures) were removed from each of 400 H. metallica flowers. Then, the flowers were covered with nylon bags to prevent the normal pollinators from pollinating the flowers. The covered flowers were divided equally into 4 groups (Groups 1-4), and each group received a different pollination treatment (see Table 1). Four weeks after the pollination treatments, the percent of flowers that produced fruit and the average mass per seed were determined for each group (see Figures 1 and 2, respectively).




Table and figures adapted from Matthias Schleuning et al., "Effects of Inbreeding, Outbreeding, and Supplemental Pollen on the Reproduction of a Hummingbird-pollinated Clonal Amazonian Herb." @2010 by The Author(s).
questions.question: 7.  The data that were averaged to produce the results shown in Figure 2 were most likely collected using which of the following pieces of equipment?

choices.D: Thermometer

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:

The following study was conducted to investigate the effects of different pollination treatments on fruit production and seed mass in a population of H. metallica.

Study

Before pollination could occur, the anthers (pollen-producing structures) were removed from each of 400 H. metallica flowers. Then, the flowers were covered with nylon bags to prevent the normal pollinators from pollinating the flowers. The covered flowers were divided equally into 4 groups (Groups 1-4), and each group received a different pollination treatment (see Table 1). Four weeks after the pollination treatments, the percent of flowers that produced fruit and the average mass per seed were determined for each group (see Figures 1 and 2, respectively).




Table and figures adapted from Matthias Schleuning et al., "Effects of Inbreeding, Outbreeding, and Supplemental Pollen on the Reproduction of a Hummingbird-pollinated Clonal Amazonian Herb." @2010 by The Author(s).
questions.question: 8. One of the questions about  H. metallica plants that the study was designed to answer was which of the following?

choices.A: Does the location of the plants in the understory of tropical rain forests determine whether the flowers are self-pollinated or cross-pollinated?
choices.B: Are the percent of flowers that produce fruit and the average mass per seed different when flowers are self-pollinated than when flowers are cross-pollinated?
choices.C: How long after the plants are pollinated does the fruit ripen?
choices.D: Are the flowers normally pollinated by hummingbirds?

questions.question: 9.  The pollination treatments received by Groups 1 and 2 differed in which of the following ways? The pollen received by each Group 1 flower was:

choices.A: from the same plant as the flower, whereas the pollen received by each Group 2 flower was from a different plant than the flower.
choices.B: from a different plant than the flower, whereas the pollen received by each Group 2 flower was from the same plant as the flower.
choices.C: collected from 1 plant, whereas the pollen received by each Group 2 flower was collected from 6 plants.
choices.D: collected from 6 plants, whereas the pollen received by each Group 2 flower was collected from 1 plant.

questions.question: 10.  For any group, the value shown in Figure 1 was most likely calculated using which of the following expressions?

questions.question: 11.  The anthers were most likely removed from the flowers for the purpose of ensuring that the flowers:

choices.D: would not be pollinated by hummingbirds.

questions.question: 12. Do the results of the study indicate that the nylon bags successfully prevented the normal pollinators from pollinating the  H. metallica flowers?

choices.A: Yes; only 20% of the flowers receiving the self-pollination treatment produced fruit.
choices.B: Yes; none of the flowers receiving the no pollination treatment produced fruit.
choices.C: No; only 20% of the flowers receiving the self-pollination treatment produced fruit.
choices.D: No; none of the flowers receiving the no pollination treatment produced fruit.

questions.question: 13. What was the total mass of the seeds produced by the Group 3 flowers?

choices.D: Cannot be determined from the given information

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:
When 2 types of bacteria found in the soil of a wet-land (land having a high water table) break down organic matter, gases are generated. Aerobic bacteria, which require , generate . Anaerobic bacteria, which require little or no , generate .


Study

At the beginning of a particular summer, 3 soil sections, each 1.5 m long, 1 m wide, and 0.6 m deep, were removed intact from the surface of each of 2 wetlands—a bog and a fen—after all live plants had been removed from the sections. Each section was placed in a separate 100 L tank having sides and a lid made entirely of glass. An instrument to measure gas emissions was mounted on the underside of the lid, above the soil. All the tanks were placed at an outdoor site near the wetlands.

Different amounts of water were added to the 3 tanks containing bog soil sections to produce a water table (WT) 1 cm above the surface (+1 cm) of the first soil section, a WT 10 cm below the surface (-10 cm) of the second soil section, and a WT 20 cm below the surface (-20 cm) of the third soil section. This procedure was repeated for the 3 tanks containing fen soil sections. All the lids were then closed.

Over the next 3 months, gas emissions from each soil section were measured, in moles of carbon per square meter (mol C/m²). Throughout this period, the temperature inside the tanks was kept the same as the outdoor temperature. Figure 1 shows the total emission of and the total emission of from each bog soil section due to bacterial activity; Figure 2 does the same for each fen soil section.
questions.question: 14. The researchers who conducted the study most likely chose to conduct it during the summer rather than during the winter because organic matter in soil is broken down:

choices.A: in the summer by aerobic bacteria only and in the winter by anaerobic bacteria only.
choices.B: in the summer by anaerobic bacteria only and in the winter by aerobic bacteria only.
choices.C: by both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria more rapidly in the summer than in the winter.
choices.D: by both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria less rapidly in the summer than in the winter.

Figure 1 shows the total emission of and the total emission of from each bog soil section due to bacterial activity; Figure 2 does the same for each fen soil section.
questions.question: 15. According to the results of the study, as the water table for the bog soil sections and the fen soil sections became progressively lower, did the total emission increase or decrease, and did the total emission increase or decrease?

choices.D: total  emission: decreasedtotal  emission: decreased

questions.question: 16. One of the reasons that the lid on each tank was kept closed for the 3-month period was to:

choices.A: minimize the amount of emitted gas that exited the tank.
choices.B: maximize the amount of atmospheric gas that entered the tank.
choices.C: prevent bacteria from leaving the tank.
choices.D: prevent sunlight from entering the tank.

questions.question: 17. The 2 types of wetland investigated in this study—bogs and fens—have different levels of the nutrients that sustain bacterial growth. Do the results of the study suggest that the levels of the nutrients that sustain aerobic bacteria are higher in bogs or in fens, and do the results of the study suggest that the levels of the nutrients that sustain anaerobic bacteria are higher in bogs or in fens?

choices.A: higher nutrients for aerobic bacteria: bogshigher nutrients for anaerobic bacteria: bogs
choices.B: higher nutrients for aerobic bacteria: bogshigher nutrients for anaerobic bacteria: fens
choices.C: higher nutrients for aerobic bacteria: fenshigher nutrients for anaerobic bacteria: bogs
choices.D: higher nutrients for aerobic bacteria: fenshigher nutrients for anaerobic bacteria: fens

questions.question: 18. Based on the results of the study for the 2 soil sections that were completely submerged in water, were aerobic bacteria present in those sections?

choices.A: Yes;  was emitted from those sections.
choices.B: Yes;  was emitted from those sections.
choices.C: No; only  was emitted from those sections.
choices.D: No; only was emitted from those sections.

questions.question: 19. Consider the total emission from the fen soil section having a WT of -10 cm. Based on that result, over the 3 months, the average emission from that soil section  per month would have been closest to which of the following?

choices.D: 19 mol C/㎡

questions.question: 20. The study was conducted at an outdoor site near the wetlands to ensure that the tanks would be nearly identical to the wetlands with respect to which of the following conditions?

choices.D: Hours of daylight

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
Physics students performed 3 studies to determine the forces that several doors exerted on their hinges. The doors had various weights, W, and widths, D. Each door had 2 hinges; the hinges could be moved to vary the distance, S, between them. None of the doors had a doorknob.


The 2 hinges on each door were equidistant from the center of mass of the door (see the diagram).



Each hinge was fitted with 2 force sensors. With the door attached to a door frame, one of the sensors detected the horizontal force exerted by the door on the hinge,, and the other sensor detected the vertical force exerted by the door on the hinge,. Once and were determined for each hinge, was averaged over the 2 hinges, yielding the average horizontal force per hinge,, and was averaged over the 2 hinges, yielding the average vertical force per hinge,· Fromand, the average net force per hinge,could be calculated.

In the 3 studies, all forces were recorded in pounds (lb) and all lengths were recorded in inches (in).


Study 1

For a door with W=61 lb and D=30 in, the students determinedandat various S. The results are shown in Figure 1.


Study 2

For 3 doors, each with D = 30 in but a different W, the students determinedat various S. The results are shown in Figure 2.



Study 3

For 3 doors, each with W = 61 lb but a different D, the students determinedat various S. The results are shown in Figure 3.
questions.question: 21. In which study, if any, was the door with the greatest mass tested?

choices.D: None of the studies; all the doors tested in the 3 studies had the same mass.

Study 3

For 3 doors, each with W = 61 lb but a different D, the students determinedat various S. The results are shown in Figure 3.
questions.question: 22. Which of the following statements regarding  W and  D best describes a difference between Study 2 and Study 3 ? In Study 2:

choices.A: W was varied while  D was held constant, whereas in Study 3,  W was held constant while  D was varied.
choices.B: W was held constant while  D was varied, whereas in Study 3,  W was varied while  D was held constant.
choices.C: both  W and  D were varied, whereas in Study 3, both  W and  D were held constant.
choices.D: both  W and  D were held constant, whereas in Study 3, both  W and  D were varied.

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
Physics students performed 3 studies to determine the forces that several doors exerted on their hinges. The doors had various weights, W, and widths, D. Each door had 2 hinges; the hinges could be moved to vary the distance, S, between them. None of the doors had a doorknob.


The 2 hinges on each door were equidistant from the center of mass of the door (see the diagram).



Each hinge was fitted with 2 force sensors. With the door attached to a door frame, one of the sensors detected the horizontal force exerted by the door on the hinge,, and the other sensor detected the vertical force exerted by the door on the hinge,. Once and were determined for each hinge, was averaged over the 2 hinges, yielding the average horizontal force per hinge,, and was averaged over the 2 hinges, yielding the average vertical force per hinge,· Fromand, the average net force per hinge,could be calculated.

In the 3 studies, all forces were recorded in pounds (lb) and all lengths were recorded in inches (in).


Study 1

For a door with W=61 lb and D=30 in, the students determinedandat various S. The results are shown in Figure 1.


Study 2

For 3 doors, each with D = 30 in but a different W, the students determinedat various S. The results are shown in Figure 2.



Study 3

For 3 doors, each with W = 61 lb but a different D, the students determinedat various S. The results are shown in Figure 3.
questions.question: 23. If a door having W = 90 lb, D=30 in, and S=50 in had been tested in Study 2,for this door would most likely have been:

choices.D: greater than 45 lb.

questions.question: 24. For the door tested in Study 1, when  S was less than 30 in, wasless thanor greater than, and when S was greater than 30 in, wasless thanor greater than?

choices.B: S less than 30 in: lessS greater than 30 in: greater

questions.question: 27. Suppose that, due to a manufacturing defect, a particular pair of hinges will break when a net force greater than 57 lb is exerted on each hinge. Based on Study 3, the hinges will most likely break if used on a 61 lb door with which of the following combinations of D and S ?

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:
In a chemistry class, the teacher placed 0.5 g of porous steel wool, composed mostly of iron (Fe), inside a small heat-resistant quartz tube. She then used silicone hoses to connect the quartz tube to 2 airtight glass syringes (see figure). Each syringe contained 8 mL of air, and the total volume of air in the closed apparatus was 20 mL.

A Bunsen burner was then used to heat the contents of the quartz tube for 2 min. During heating, the plungers were moved up and down to pass the air back and forth through the steel wool. The total volume of gas in the apparatus steadily declined over the 2 min. Once the apparatus and its contents returned to room temperature, the total volume of gas in the apparatus was 16 mL.

The teacher asked each of 4 students to explain what occurred during the demonstration.

Student 1

During heating, the Fe in the steel wool reacted with all the in the air to form solid iron nitride (FeN), which was deposited on the steel wool. Air contains about 20% by volume. As a result of the reaction, the total volume of gas in the apparatus decreased by about 20%, so almost all the gas remaining in the apparatus was .

Student 2

During heating, the Fe in the steel wool reacted with some of the in the air to form solid iron oxide (), which was deposited on the steel wool. Air contains about 80% by volume. As a result of the reaction, the total volume of gas in the apparatus decreased by about 20%. Almost all the gas remaining in the apparatus was a mixture of about 75% and 25% by volume.

Student 3

Student 2 is correct, except that (1) the Fe in the steel wool reacted with all the , in the air and (2)air contains about 20% by volume. After the reaction, almost all the gas remaining in the apparatus was .

Student 4

During heating, the Fe in the steel wool reacted with all the in the air to form solid iron carbonate (), which was deposited on the steel wool. Air contains about 20% by volume. As a result of the reaction, the total volume of gas in the apparatus decreased by about 20%, so almost all the gas remaining in the apparatus was .
questions.question: 28. Air contains less than 1% argon by volume. This information weakens the explanations given by which of the students, if any?

choices.D: None of the students

questions.question: 29. Silicone hoses were most likely used to connect the quartz tube to the syringes because silicone has which of the properties listed below? I. Strong resistance to heat II. Low chemical reactivity III. High solubility in water

choices.D: I, II, and III

choices.D: Student 4

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:
Quarks constitute 1 of the 3 classes of elementary particles that form all matter in the universe. Three quarks bound together form a type of particle called a baryon. A quark's effective mass (mass when bound to other quarks) is greater than its single-quark mass (mass when unbound). In addition spin-down ().

Table 1 lists the symbol, electric charge, and approximate single-quark mass for each of the 6 quarks.



Table 2 gives the symbol, mass, quark content, and quark spins for several baryons.


Tables adapted from C. Amsler et al., "Review of Particle Physics." ©2008 by Elsevier B.V.
questions.question: 35. For all quarks, the amount of spin is always , where  is a constant.  A spin-up quark has spin , and a spin-down quark has spin . Given that the spin of a baryon equals the sum of its quark spins, what are the spins of the  and  baryons listed in Table 2 ?

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:
Quarks constitute 1 of the 3 classes of elementary particles that form all matter in the universe. Three quarks bound together form a type of particle called a baryon. A quark's effective mass (mass when bound to other quarks) is greater than its single-quark mass (mass when unbound). In addition, all quarks possess a property called spin. A quark's spin can be oriented in 1 of 2 directions, spin-up () or spin-down ().

Table 1 lists the symbol, electric charge, and approximate single-quark mass for each of the 6 quarks.



Table 2 gives the symbol, mass, quark content, and quark spins for several baryons.


Tables adapted from C. Amsler et al., "Review of Particle Physics." ©2008 by Elsevier B.V.
questions.question: 36. Which of the following diagrams represents the quark content and quark spins for an electrically neutral baryon having only 2 quark spins oriented in the same direction?

Tables adapted from C. Amsler et al., "Review of Particle Physics." ©2008 by Elsevier B.V.
questions.question: 37. Is the information in Tables 1 and 2 consistent with the known electric charge for the proton?

choices.A: No, because Tables 1 and 2 indicate the proton has an electric charge of 0.
choices.B: No, because Tables 1 and 2 indicate the proton has an electric charge of +1.
choices.C: Yes, because Tables 1 and 2 indicate the proton has an electric charge of 0.
choices.D: Yes, because Tables 1 and 2 indicate the proton has an electric charge of +1.

choices.D: usc

questions.question: 40. The 6 quarks are grouped into 3 generations as shown in the table below. For which generation, if any, is the statement "Positively charged quarks are more massive than negatively charged quarks”  NOT true?

choices.D: None of the generations; the statement is true for all 3 generations.
